body:
Reducing the size of `sequence_name` and `sequence_prev_id` column (for example, to 127) could be a solution for the issue.
Or, we can recommend to use InnoDB with `set global innodb_large_prefix=on`.
I'm not sure which one is better or another good way to solve the issue.
@nishantmonu51 Thanks for your information.
@sirpkt Thanks for the report. What version of druid are you seeing this error on?

What exactly are you trying to accomplish here?

My issue with adding or overriding java options is that it is very easy to screw up. Meaning that you have two configurations you have to keep in sync (default java options and task java options).

Even adding "extraJavaOpts" runs the risk of someone changing the origin javaOpts to have incompatible or weird flags.

Can you give an idea of the use cases you are trying to solve by exposing javaOpts?

That table is from #1896 so probably a build from master. Given that it's not in a release yet, I think it'd be ok to make a backwards incompatible change like changing it to VARBINARY (assuming that works on derby/mysql/postgresql) or changing the index to be on a new column like sequence_name_prev_id_sha1 (sha1 of both those fields).

Thanks for the catch @sirpkt.

FYI: This CREATE TABLE had worked for me using InnoDB on MySQL 5.6.27. http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.6/en/innodb-restrictions.html seems to imply that InnoDB can do a multi-column index that is longer than 767 bytes, up to 3072 bytes total (but not more than 767 bytes per column) so I guess that makes sense.
:+1: after travis

@CHOIJAEHONG1 Cool. once https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2246 is done, I was hoping an extra feature to be able to add JVM modules in a "better" way, such that you could add things like the Debugger properties you mentioned, or enable jmxremote or other JVM level stuff. And the modules would have basic capacities to append to the javaOpts to configure the properties, AND be able to communicate any job resource needs that it adds (ex: more ports, more memory, more cpu load)
since the context javaOpts solves this for the short term, would something like what I described solve it for the longer term?
@himanshug can you take a look?
@drcrallen Thanks for the review, updated as per your comments. Please review when you get chance :)
@gianm instead, should we just make innodb a requirement for Druid 0.9?

@xvrl I think we should definitely make innodb a recommendation, but I think it's nice to support other storage engines if possible, to make life easier for people that already have tables in those engines (migrating metadata is a pain)

@fjy my comment here was not addressed https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2014/files#r49129298
Can we please make sure to review all comments before hitting merge?
:+1: after comments regarding StringUtils.toUtf8 are addressed.
@himanshug @drcrallen switched to StringUtils.toUtf8

Prior behavior is to prioritize by month, and if months are equal, to prioritize on the DataSegment identifier.

This PR changes behavior to load based on complete timestamp of the start of the interval for the DataSegment.

The proposed behavior deviates from prior in that segments with smaller granularity will be favored more in this Comparator compared to the prior Comparator. (ex: Hour segments will be favored over Day segments).

Is there any risk the Coordinator segment balancer will spend too long just balancing batches of hour segments, and won't ever try to rebalance older segments?
Is there a reason this needs to be in druid core and not an extension?

+1  after checks
(but I'm curious as to why you chose not to divide the test code into two separate tests.)
@rasahner purely because all of if was related and still kept test simple.

@drcrallen thanks for the comments, to answer to your question, @cheddar suggested that since `LookupExtractor` is part of the druid core code this its ref manager should also exist at the druid core.

@xvrl I agree with you that Announcer will become less useful overtime, and it's probably not necessary to use it for discovery purpose. If I understand correctly, are you suggesting carry payload in curator ServiceInstance? (currently we set payload to Void)
@cheddar , @xvrl and @drcrallen is this what you are expecting

@drcrallen yeah, forgot about that yesterday =\

I was able to re-open it though by doing a "git reset --hard" to the SHA at the time the PR was closed

@b-slim `LookupDelegator` is NOT in core druid until this patch. And the manager isn't on `LookupExtractor`, it is on `LookupDelegator` unless I'm misreading something

If the answer is "`LookupDelegator` and its manager could be in a module but I don't want it in one" that's a declaration you can make, but I was under the impression that if things can reasonably be in modules they probably should be to keep the core druid as un-muddled as possible.
@xvrl looks like @gianm went and added hash/equals so that commit is removed now.

@guobingkun yes, for internal discovery we can use the payload to pass information.
We will probably want to have two distinct announcers for internal and external purposes anyway for two reasons:
- we want to allow different ZK connection strings for internal and external use
- we want to allow someone to replace the external announcer with their own implementation that may carry other information in the payload
Tentatively adding a Release Notes tag here, though I'm not quite certain what to say about it other than "version may require more testing than normal to ensure your configs don't get weird"
Actual failure... investigating.
@jon-wei FYI
@drcrallen cool, thanks for the notice
@gianm @rasahner @himanshug These docs do not recommend using real-time nodes. Thoughts?

@drcrallen Context javaOpts is enough to solve the problem nicely. It sounds good to have that feature you mentioned, especially when it comes to dealing with YARN or MESOS and providing such functionalities based on them refering to #2246, I guess.

@drcrallen `LookupDelegator` is here for backward compatibility reason, once we move on, invocation of Lookups will directly  via dimensionSpec and hence managed by this manager. First, there is no reason to  nest the lookups under extraction function then under namespacedLookup. Second i don't think it makes thing muddy, this will provide a straightforward way of using any thing that implements the core interface `LookupExtrator`. But i do i agree with you that implementation of `LookupExtractor` should be an extension. Hope this makes thing clear !
@himanshug have you thought at all about extending this PR and enabling on disk computations with groupBys?
@himank do you mind following the steps here? https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/1Zs3Vd9LHCQ so your contribution will be counted :)
@himanshug ?

@fjy This is a self-sufficient step that has immediate gains without introducing any major query latency.

I'm thinking about on-disk, but it is a challenge to do that without adding significant query latency... currently, I'm in the stage of brainstorming on that in the background. That said, current PR might enable larger groupBys than before.
`AnnouncerTest.testSessionKilled:176 »  test timed out after 60000 milliseconds`

Hello,

Please go through this [document](http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/rolling-updates.html) for questions about rolling updates to druid cluster. For questions about multitenancy go through this [document](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/operations/multitenancy.md).

If you have any further questions please use druid-user google group for asking questions as you can expect much faster response there. Here's the [link](https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!forum/druid-user)
Rebased on master, barely. I'll address comments.
Because there is so many conflicts, I think I should rebase this after #2094 is merged.

@b-slim in your comment you say this is blocking development of QTL, but it's unclear what this is blocking. Can you and @drcrallen work together to put together an issue that lays out the proposal for what still needs to be done, so development can be discussed there? I feel there hasn't been enough discussion or collaboration around the topic, and it's unclear what is in the works, or what still needs to be completed. It would also help discuss proposed changes and avoid duplicate / conflicting efforts.
@xvrl Totally my bad, sorry. I've added patch for it in #2326.
Is there any update on this?
@xvrl, just i want to mention that @cheddar and @drcrallen had a couple of meetings to talk and discuss what it is missing and what should be doing.

I think it's not necessary, or even desirable, to wait until the implementation is complete before having user-facing documentation, at least in draft form.  It's a useful way to state what problem is being solved (what the requirements are).  It can also suggest integration tests.

That's why I proposed https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2286 as the communication / http endpoints, https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1576 to do the management and coordinator side. This approach was originally for dimension extraction lookups, but might be able to be adopted / modified for this case.
@rasahner I think what you're describing is a proposal.The User docs are a major pain to keep in sync with the development docs as code reviews change things.

@xvrl I took a stab at the "top level issue": https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2329

Hopefully that provides the color you were looking for?

@abbondanza Thanks for the contrib! Do you mind filling out: http://druid.io/community/cla.html?

Will merge it after

Fwiw, I'm more in favor of using the `Announcer`.  Curator service discovery leaves a lot of turds lying around in ZK and has a whole bunch of extra junk in the znodes.  Also, the argument about replacing it.  Using Curator discovery is likely to make it significantly more difficult to replace this, where using `Announcer` will keep the surface area of announcement contained and simpler to replace.

Fwiw, I think that replacing the "announcing" of service availability is the simplest of the things to swap off of ZK.  After that, we can adjust the publishing logic (segment announcements).  So, keeping in mind that we hope to follow this up with an HTTP implementation of the Announcer in the not too distant future, I'd be more in favor of sticking with an interface we have more control over instead of expanding the scope of the removal of ZK to also force us to reimplement the entire curator service discovery interface.

@fjy You got it! I filled it out..

I hope to contribute more in the future :+1:
would be worth mentioning the stuff in `namespace-lookup` is intended for use in "small" `Map` objects.
@abbondanza You might also want to follow https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-development/1Zs3Vd9LHCQ if you haven't done so already
@himanshug I think we should make this feature an optional query flag, and disable it by default until there is a more robust implementation.

@drcrallen unless i am missing something and don't see how #2286 or #1576 cover the first item which is the first basic brick. Then of course will come to the point on how to do the distributed config process and thought you had a couple of meeting with @guobingkun to hopefully agrees upon one way to do the thing
@xvrl SGTM ... let me do a PR to make that configurable.

So, there are a couple of fixes that need to be done I think.  
1. The big one that this highlights is that we do not have any size checks on the payload sent back in the header.  We should fix that and have something that verifies the size of what we are sending back.  If it is too large, we should log and send back a different header instead.
   
   The fix to add "uncoveredIntervals" has exposed the bug, but it is not the only thing that could potentially cause problems here.
2. I'm fine with hiding uncoveredIntervals behind a feature flag.  We could also add a configurable limit to how many intervals are put in the list so that we try to make sure that we aren't overloading things.  If we have more than 20 intervals, for example, we just say "many intervals didn't have data" and move on.
There should be a configuration in jetty to increase the allowed header size as well. Currently there's not a great way to configure jetty options within Druid though.
so (2) is still needed and (1) needs to be done in parallel. created https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2331 to track (1) separately.

@drcrallen while there is theoretically no limit to http header sizes, I am worried increasing the header size could cause interoperability issues with browsers, proxies, or other http clients querying Druid. Most of those set limits on the size of http headers, which the user may not have much control over.
would it be worth investigating http trailer support at all?

@cheddar I don't think any implementation is going to be harder to replace than the other. The only interface we'd have to reimplement is whichever abstraction we are building on top of Announcer or Curator discovery to do internal node announcement.

That being said, I don't have a very strong preference over which announcement implementation we use, as long as we offer an easy abstraction to discover nodes within the cluster. Indeed, the reason curator was misused in the first place was due to its simplicity and because existing announcer based discovery protocols were tied to segment announcement or tied to indexing service specifics, making it harder to re-use those pieces for pure node discovery.
@himanshug @fjy maybe it would be worth using whichever abstraction we develop as part of #2040 for internal discovery.

@himanshug I think can get behind this PR if the intention is to offer a simple entry-point to make queries. However, I think we should consider re-using the router servlet to implement request forwarding instead of implementing yet another proxy servlet. It shouldn't be too hard to abstract the router-specific pieces to make it re-usable. Happy to help you out if you're interested.

one simple option is to put a check in QueryResource on size of header and truncate any header to something like 4k and log.warn("blah header was truncated").
not sure if there is a way to reliably determine "4k".

Fwiw, I think that the "solution" Druid implements for (1) can be as simple "if the content of the query ocntext map is greater than 2kb, log it and replace it with a UUID that can be used to find the log"
@xvrl @cheddar @drcrallen pls put comments relevant to (1) in  #2331

@himanshug @cheddar it might be worthwhile to think of what is necessary vs. nice to have in the response context. Dropping all of it just because one entry doesn't fit seems a bit heavy-handed.

Some pieces of the response context are going to be used programmatically and expected to be present, others are more informational in nature.

One solution would be to say it should be the responsibility of whichever code is adding to the context to not exceed a certain size, and hope we don't have too many things writing to the context.

Another might be to have a separate section of the context that can be dropped and logged if needed.
We already have a query UUID so we can just reuse that in the log.

@xvrl currently whole response context map is dumped in single header, we can create one "X-Druid-Response-Context-<key>"  for each key in the map and truncate individually if they are larger than 4K .
we might end up having multiple headers but i don't think there is a limit as such on number of headers.. in any case number of entries in response context map should be smallish.

> Some pieces of the response context are going to be used programmatically and expected to be present, others are more informational in nature.

@xvrl shouldn't the points of code looking at the context be robust to it not being there?  AFAIK, the context is informational at best, not actually a necessary part for functionality.  If it is being used as a necessary part of the flow instead of just informational purposes, I think we should re-evaluate its status as an HTTP Header...

@nishantmonu51 concern pointed by @drcrallen might be very real when you have 2 dataSources with segments of 15min and hour/day granularity , it will be good if we can incorporate the the interval size into the comparator too.
other than that LGTM
As per @cheddar 's comments in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2040#issuecomment-174605281 this probably should start off with an Announcer-like interface rather than using ServiceDiscovery.
Rebased on master. Now incremental index also returns estimated size.
Fixed by #2076
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid-api/pull/65
Fixed by #1936
rebased

Hi @gianm, I am sorry that I did not reply to you straight away. I felt that I needed to wait for the new year for my feelings on the subject to brew.

There is nothing like TIME_PART in general SQL as far as I know BUT the in most SQLs there are two things:
1. Lots and lots of basic time functions like (from: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/date-and-time-functions.html ):
   - `MINUTE()` - MINUTE_OF_HOUR in my suggestion
   - `HOUR()` - HOUR_OF_DAY in my suggestion
   - `WEEKOFYEAR()` - WEEK_OF_YEAR in my suggestion
2. Ability to compose those very easily with Maths `HOUR(d)*60+MINUTE(d) AS "MINUTE_OF_DAY"`

In Plywood/PlyQL I thought it would be cool to lump all of these together into one function and then extend it will all the logical X_OF_Y. I did not want to ask for an extraction function for every function supported by MySQL but that would be fine as well. I figured that a good API would be to have a `timePart` extraction function with whatever subset of time parting functions you think makes sense.

ok, it doesn't matter whether we have one header for each element in the responseContext map ...jetty uses one Buffer to hold all the headers.
best we can do really is to truncate the result of `jsonMapper.writeValueAsString(responseContext)` to 4k-8k or something. and it should be ok or else query will fail if responseContext accidentally has more stuff than 8k.
Rebased, anyway.

@du00cs it should not be too hard to implement using the [parquet input format](https://github.com/Parquet/parquet-mr/blob/master/parquet-hadoop/src/main/java/parquet/hadoop/ParquetInputFormat.java). If you want to take a stab at implementing an extension, please do, I think it would be a great contribution!

Also @guobingkun for doc stuff please use the [Documentation] label in the PR.

Bracketed tags in the commit or pr name of your own design are fine, but searching/sorting in the PRs work better with the github labels.
Spoke with @cheddar a bit yesterday and will be implementing some of the suggestions. namely: move the AbstractGET/POST/DELETE to a single class.

@du00cs the best place to start is to look at how the Avro extension was implemented: 
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/master/extensions/avro-extensions
@du00cs Definitely think this is useful

https://github.com/Parquet/parquet-mr/blob/master/parquet-hadoop/src/main/java/parquet/hadoop/ParquetInputFormat.java is `ParquetInputFormat<T>` , I think you can use that InputFormat as it is and write an InputRowParser that parses T in druid InputRow . That should be enough.
Fixed by #2315 , thanks @rasahner !

@drcrallen @himanshug: In prior behavior for segments with same month, we used to order things by the dataSource name as the segment Identifier starts with the dataSource, So in case of 2 dataSources with segments of 15min and hour/day granularity, It will favor the one whose name comes first lexicographically instead of depending on segment granularity. 

For proposed behavior, how do you feel about the comparator being changed to compare IntervalEndThenStart to always load the segments having more recent data first ?
@nishantmonu51 I think that's a bit better than either prior case or the first proposed case in this PR.
